Under a communism-based system, the idea is that the government or a collective owns and controls the means of production and distribution of resources, rather than these things being owned and controlled by individuals or private businesses. This means that resources would be allocated based on the needs of the community, rather than being allocated based on the ability of individuals to pay for them.

While this type of system can be effective at reducing inequalities and ensuring that basic needs are met for all members of the community, it can also stifle innovation and economic growth. In a monetary-based system, individuals and businesses have an incentive to produce goods and services that people are willing to pay for, which can lead to innovation and economic growth. In a resource-allocation based system, there may not be as strong of an incentive for individuals and businesses to be productive and innovative, as resources are allocated regardless of their ability to generate income or profits.
